metadata.sermon_title: Trinity Sunday / Second Sunday After Pentecost
metadata.notes: The sermon combines a Trinitarian theology of love with a traditionalist emphasis on total depravity ('miserable offenders').

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher utilizes a strong Critical Parent voice to lament the loss of 'miserable offenders' language, effectively shaming the modern church for removing 'there is no health in us.'
quotes: The removal of this line has robbed us...
The depth... is the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'
There is something fundamentally, drastically, terribly wrong with all of us.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent appears through the metaphor of the desperate parent and the 'hint' of human love, though it is used to set up the necessity of the Critical Parent's diagnosis.
quotes: You would do anything, anything at all, to reverse the situation.
Think of those who did not seem to have much self-regard as they poured all their resources into you.

adult.analysis: While the preacher uses historical data (prayer book changes) and linguistic analysis, the goal is not objective reflection but to drive the listener back into a Child state of dependency.
quotes: In the version that we used until 1976...
Notice the surprising order of the words...

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly invites the listener into the Adapted Child role—specifically the 'Miserable Offender'—suggesting that only through this self-abasement can one be 'saved.'
quotes: Lord, have mercy on me, a sinner.
Before God, none of us can hold up our heads.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a glimpse of Free Child in the 'beautiful, ecstatic imagery' of the watchman and the 'joyous and liberating knowledge,' though it is strictly conditional on the Parent's approval.
quotes: Straining forward to the approach of the dawn.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher establishes a Parent-Child dynamic where the preacher (as the voice of the Church/Law) diagnoses the listener's 'total inability' and 'wretchedness,' inviting a submissive Adapted Child response.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: The social message is 'God loves you,' but the psychological message is 'You are fundamentally broken and unhealthy.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' is that the promise of 'grace' is only accessible if the listener first accepts a crushing psychological diagnosis of having 'no health' in them.

detected_games.name: NIGYSOB (Now I've Got You, You Son of a Bitch)

formula_g_analysis.con: The promise of a 'full Trinitarian blessing.'
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's inherent sense of guilt or inadequacy.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Moving from the 'love of God' to the 'miserable offender' and 'no health in us' diagnosis.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels small and dependent; the preacher reinforces the authority of the 'old' ways.

evidence_quotes: If you, O Lord, were to note what is done amiss, Lord, who could stand?

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch

formula_g_analysis.con: Opening with a relatable, nurturing story of a parent's love for a child.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire for unconditional acceptance.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The shift to the 'vast primordial catastrophe' and the requirement of fearing God's majesty.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener accepts a low-status position ('miserable offender') to regain the 'love' offered in the 'con'.

evidence_quotes: This is no dry scholarly doctrine... yet... there is no health in us.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. Offers the 'apostolic blessing' and 'mercy' as the only cure for the catastrophe.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Medium. Labels the listener as having 'no health' and being a 'miserable offender.'
preacher_roles.victim: Low. Paul is framed as the 'agonized' parent, but the preacher remains in the Rescuer/Persecutor seat.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is pushed into the 'Victim' role—powerless, unhealthy, and unable to 'hold up their heads.'
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon offers 'deliverance,' but only through the cycle of the triangle (admitting Victimhood to be saved by the Rescuer). It does not promote Adult autonomy.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is psychologically regressive. It utilizes a 'shame-based' homiletic that requires the listener to adopt a 'No-OK' position ('no health in us') to make the 'God-is-OK' position meaningful. While it uses the language of love, it creates a dependency loop where the listener must feel 'miserable' to experience 'mercy.' This reinforces an Adapted Child ego state rather than an Adult faith.
strengths: Strong use of metaphor (the desperate parent).
High emotional resonance and 'Free Child' imagery in the conclusion.
areas_for_improvement: Over-reliance on Critical Parent judgments regarding liturgical changes.
Theological 'double-bind': telling the listener they are loved while simultaneously telling them they are 'fundamentally wrong'.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Address the congregation as 'Adults' capable of moral agency. Instead of insisting on 'no health in us,' explore how the 'Adult' can partner with the 'Divine' to address real-world 'catastrophes' without requiring total self-abasement.
